examples.text: She is still weak after her illness.
His legs felt weak.
She suffered from a weak heart.
I was exhausted and weak with hunger.
Her legs felt suddenly weak.
She was weak from shock.
When the spasm passed, it left him weak and sweating.

definitions.definition: that cannot support a lot of weight; likely to break

examples.text: That bridge is too weak for heavy traffic.
Weak foundations caused the building to collapse.

definitions.definition: easy to influence; not having much power

examples.text: a weak and cowardly man
In a weak moment *(= when I was easily persuaded)* I said she could borrow the car.
Small firms find themselves in a very weak position during a recession.
a weak leader
The unions have always been weak in this industry.

definitions.definition: people who are poor, sick or without power

examples.text: A **weak dollar** isn't bad news for everyone.
a weak currency/yen/euro
Is it your policy to have a relatively weak currency?
The **economy** is very **weak**.
The currency was still relatively weak against the dollar.

definitions.definition: a weak liquid contains a lot of water

examples.text: weak tea
a weak acid
a weak light/signal/sound
The weak winter sunlight spread across the lake.
a weak team
I was always weak in the science subjects.
He's weak in English.
She's rather weak at languages.

definitions.definition: that people are not likely to believe or be persuaded by

examples.text: weak arguments/evidence
I enjoyed the movie but I thought the ending was very weak.
The case for the prosecution was rather weak.
The judge decided the evidence was inherently weak and inconsistent.
The essay was a bit weak on detail.
a weak smile
He made a weak attempt to look cheerful.

definitions.definition: the part of a person’s character, an argument, etc. that is easy to attack or criticize

examples.text: The team's weak points are in defence.
He knew her weak spot where Steve was concerned.

definitions.definition: a weak verb forms the past tense and past participle by adding a regular ending and not by changing a vowel. In English this is done by adding -d, -ed or -t (for example walk, walked).
used when there is no stress on the word. For example, the weak form of and is /ən/ or /n/, as in fish and chips /fɪʃ ən tʃɪps/.
you intend to do good things but you are too lazy, weak or busy to actually do them
hardly able to stand because of emotion, fear, illness, etc.

examples.text: His sudden smile made her go weak at the knees.

definitions.definition: the point at which a system or an organization is most likely to fail

examples.text: She went straight for the one weak link in the chain of his argument.

wordOrigin: Old English wāc ‘pliant’, ‘of little worth’, ‘not steadfast’, reinforced in Middle English by Old Norse veikr, from a Germanic base meaning ‘yield, give way’.
